entry.title: The 8D Architectural Framework for SAP ERP Modernization: A Practitioner‚Äôs View
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • 1D ‚Äî Regulatory Envelope
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • 2D ‚Äî AI Ambition vs. Process Intelligence Reality
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • 3D ‚Äî Data Governance as Technical Foundation
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • 4D ‚Äî Clean Core Extensibility (SAP BTP-Centric Architecture)
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • 5D ‚Äî Deployment Model as an Architectural Outcome
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • 6D ‚Äî Change Management for Technical Adoption
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • 7D ‚Äî Competitive Timeline (Architecture Maturity Curve)
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • 8D ‚Äî 15-Year Architectural Vision (Composable, AI-Ready ERP)
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • Conclusion
  • Call for Discussion

Introduction

After 20 years across SAP roles (ABAP through Pre-Sales Architecture), I've observed one constant: transformation projects fail not because of technical complexity, but because architects evaluate decisions along too few dimensions. This 8D ERP Transformation Framework provides the lens for holistic evaluation. This framework emerges from observing S/4HANA 2025 release capabilities and the architectural options they enable. 

Architects succeed when they evaluate ERP transformation through multiple dimensions, not just scope or timelines.

This 8D ERP Transformation Framework is a practical lens for architects, technical leads, and industry experts to evaluate modernization decisions holistically ‚Äî aligning with SAP best practices while ensuring long-term architectural integrity.

1D ‚Äî Regulatory Envelope

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
Before discussing deployment models or system design, architects should begin with a clear understanding of industry-specific regulatory constraints. Not as limitation‚Äîas the architectural guardrails that enable good design. Pharma needs GxP-validated processes. Banking needs SOX audit trails. Healthcare needs HIPAA data residency. These requirements, when understood first, shape architectures that are both compliant AND competitive.

Why it matters

  • Determines data residency, encryption, auditability
  • Influences deployment model suitability (public, private, hybrid)
  • Shapes integration patterns (secure interfaces, segregation of duties)
  • Impacts AI governance and validation requirements

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Start here. Regulation isn‚Äôt a blocker ‚Äî it provides the boundaries within which good architecture is designed.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúHow are architects incorporating GxP, SOX, or enterprise data sovereignty into their S/4HANA designs?‚Äù

2D ‚Äî AI Ambition vs. Process Intelligence Reality

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
AI potential is immense, but technical feasibility depends on process maturity and system standardization.

Why it matters

  • AI needs predictable, event-driven processes
  • Variants or undocumented steps make automation unreliable
  • Process mining (Signavio, Celonis) gives architects clarity on actual execution paths
  • Architectural patterns must align with future AI scenarios

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Map ‚Üí standardize ‚Üí instrument ‚Üí automate.
AI-readiness should be treated as a technical design requirement, not a future add-on.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúHow are teams using process intelligence during Explore/Design phases to define AI-ready to-be processes?‚Äù

3D ‚Äî Data Governance as Technical Foundation

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
ERP modernization gives architects a rare opportunity to redesign master data models, lineage, governance, and integration semantics.

Why it matters

  • Data lineage is essential for audit and AI explainability
  • Data quality (>95% accuracy) supports automation reliability
  • Master Data governance enables clean integration landscapes
  • Event-driven designs require consistent data domains

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Treat data governance as a core architecture pillar ‚Äî not a post-go-live enhancement.
Modern ERP + AI depends on structured, governed data models.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúWhat architecture patterns (Datasphere, MDM, governance councils) are teams adopting to ensure cross-system consistency?‚Äù

4D ‚Äî Clean Core Extensibility (SAP BTP-Centric Architecture)

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
Clean core is an architectural strategy that balances stability with innovation. It aligns tightly with SAP‚Äôs guidance while enabling teams to innovate using BTP.

Why it matters

  • Core remains upgrade-friendly, consistent, and supportable
  • Extensions move to BTP (RAP, CAP, ABAP Cloud)
  • Reduces complexity, accelerates lifecycle management
  • API-first design supports AI, mobility, and cloud-native integrations

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Design for extensibility beyond the core.
Architects should evaluate each customization:

  • Is this differentiating?
  • Can it live on BTP?
  • Can it follow RAP/CAP patterns?

Example: Procurement customization. Is it differentiating? If yes, build on BTP using RAP patterns. Is it standard? Keep in core. Can it use ABAP Cloud with stable APIs? Yes. This decision-tree approach prevents accumulation of technical debt.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúHow are architects managing custom code remediation and defining clean-core guardrails during design?‚Äù

5D ‚Äî Deployment Model as an Architectural Outcome

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
Public Cloud, Private Cloud, On-Premise, and Hybrid models each have strengths. The right choice emerges after evaluating regulatory, data, integration, and extensibility needs.

Why it matters

  • Public Cloud offers rapid innovation and standardization
  • Private Cloud offers control, extensibility, and harmonization flexibility
  • Hybrid architectures support OT/IoT-heavy industries
  • Deployment must align with technical and business constraints

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Deployment selection is a conclusion ‚Äî not the starting point.
Architects should let the earlier dimensions drive the model.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúHow are teams balancing innovation velocity with integration depth when selecting deployment models?‚Äù

6D ‚Äî Change Management for Technical Adoption

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
Change management isn‚Äôt just business-focused. Architects must plan for technical change adoption: new workflows, new UX, new AI features, new integration patterns.

Why it matters

  • AI-enabled ERP shifts user behavior
  • Role design must consider AI agents and automated tasks
  • Continuous enablement ensures stable operations
  • Architecture must support explainability and feedback loops

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Technical design must include a human adoption model.
UX, security, audit, and automation patterns must be communicated early.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúHow are architects designing role/permission models for AI-augmented processes?‚Äù

7D ‚Äî Competitive Timeline (Architecture Maturity Curve)

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
Timelines are not only logistical ‚Äî they determine how fast architecture matures to support modern capabilities.

Why it matters

  • Event-driven integrations, BTP services, and AI agents require iterative maturation
  • Early modernization accelerates capability-building
  • Late modernization compresses architecture redesign into a shorter window

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Treat modernization as capability-building, not only project execution.
Teams that start earlier build deeper technical skillsets and more stable architectures.

Real data point: Organizations that began S/4HANA transformation in 2023-2024 now deploy new capabilities 3x faster than those starting in 2025-2026, not just because of resource availability but because their technical teams have matured architectural thinking. Early movers built composable architectures; late movers are compressed into shortcuts.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúHow are organizations sequencing modernization waves to align with capability growth?‚Äù

8D ‚Äî 15-Year Architectural Vision (Composable, AI-Ready ERP)

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
S/4HANA support extends to 2040, meaning today‚Äôs architecture must support a decade of evolving AI, integration, and business models.

Why it matters

  • Composability allows modular replacements without major disruption
  • API-first architecture enables multi-platform ecosystems
  • Datasphere, event mesh, knowledge graphs, and vector stores reshape data layers
  • Hybrid/multi-cloud is increasingly standard

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Architect beyond go-live.
Design for interoperability, scale, observability, and long-term flexibility.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúWhat architectural patterns ensure ERP landscapes remain adaptable through 2035‚Äì2040?‚Äù

Conclusion

These eight dimensions guide architects to design ERP landscapes that are:

  • technically robust,
  • clean-core aligned,
  • governable,
  • scalable,
  • AI-ready,
  • and compliant with SAP best practices.

They are not sequential ‚Äî they are an interconnected model. Skip any dimension, and the others collapse under unexamined assumptions. Architects who evaluate all eight simultaneously design landscapes that survive 2030 and thrive through 2040. Those who optimize one or two while ignoring the rest? They're designing for today's constraints while tomorrow's competitors design for tomorrow's capabilities.

Call for Discussion 

  • Which dimensions are shaping your S/4HANA architecture most strongly today? Please share in comments‚ÄîI'll synthesize responses into a follow-up article on 'The 80/20: Which Two Dimensions Determine 80% of Success.

entry.title: A journey from Netweaver 7.50 to S/4HANA - Part 4: Custom Code Conversion Conundrums
entry.content:
After the preliminary steps for our custom code conversion described in part 1, part 2 and part 3 of this blog series, we finally started the actual coding activity over the summer.

To begin with, about 120 objects needed to be tackled which had been classified as high priority by the functional and business teams, many of which would most likely be needed for process testing in the first of eventual four sandbox systems. Once done with those, a big list with about 2,500 objects needed to be processed by our development team. For this blog post I picked three issues we encountered and briefly describe how we tackled them.

What to do with customer master creation or updates via XD01 and XD02?

We have several programs which create new customers or update existing customers via batch input (or call transaction) logic based on transaction XD01/02 and targeting the "old" tables KNA1, KNB1, KNVV, etc.  While the tables still exist in S/4HANA, the transactions are no longer functional because customers now have to be created and maintained as business partners via transaction BP and the business partner tables are in the "lead". The old tables are then filled from the BP, so are still available but only for read access.

Some of our logic creates customers in bulk based on file uploads and we needed an alternative route for that because many users are relying on that logic. Other programs call XD02 in order to update some fields in the customer master. Searching for alternatives, we happened upon class CL_MD_BP_MAINTAIN and method MAINTAIN, which - based on OSS Note 2484299 - BAPI list for BP - is the recommended "tool" in S/4HANA for these kind of tasks (the BAPIs (FMs) listed in the note are intended for an ECC-system).

At first glance, using this class and method looked straight-forward enough, given that it only requires one import parameter:

cl_md_bp_maintain=>maintain(
  EXPORTING
    i_data   = l_data
  IMPORTING
    e_return = l_return ).

The "fun" really started once we realised what this parameter "i_data" really is ... very deeply nested structure CVIS_EI_EXTERN! The "complex" in the description doesn't really do it justice - at the very least, I would have added an "extremely" before "complex"!

High level definition of deeply nested structure CVIS_EI_EXTERN

To get a better handle on what I was looking at, I extended all the structures and all of their sub-structures until reaching the lowest nesting level for each of them.  I then downloaded everything into a spreadsheet which ended up having 18(!) nested levels in columns A to R and over 32,000(!!!) rows. Here is a small snippet taken from the spreadsheet:

Green rows are for fields, blue lines indicate a (sub)structure and yellow rows tabletypes.

Based on a code example found in a helpful blog post here in SAP Community, we started to piece together the code needed to fill this gigantic structure in order to create a new customer in our system. By now, we do have some working code but are still working out some details for specific cases where only some fields need to be updated instead a new customer created.

Syntax error while testing logic for Australia but due to a vanished table related to Taiwan

As most of you will already know, SAP calls the OSS-notes related to a conversion to S/4HANA "Simplification Items" because SAP simplified the underlying database by eliminating tables and table fields and - to state the obvious - this makes the switch to S/4HANA anything but simple, at least if you have a large custom code base like we do! 

While our development team has been working through the custom code conversion, other teams are already testing processes in sandbox systems. These were created based on productive systems which - even though the code is sourced from the same development system - differ in the data they contain. One is for example a small system for only one company code, while another one is used in Asian-Pacific countries, so is much larger than the first sandbox to be converted and also covers many more test cases. Testing processes related to webshop orders for Australia came to a stop when the logic ran into a syntax error because a table and its structure needed for e-documents in Taiwan was found missing.

Dump due to a syntax error

The table KNA1_TW_EXT contains just a handful of fields but they are legal requirements in Taiwan for invoices. A simplification item exists for the table but it's only the rather generic one mentioning objects no longer available in S/4HANA and it doesn't go into anything specific: 2296016 - SAP S/4HANA custom code adaptation - removal of orphaned objects. So, we were wondering what happens to the data stored in the productive system in ECC during system conversion?

Digging around a bit more, I found OSS-Note 3166424 - eDocument Taiwan: Migrate Extension Fields for Electronic Documents for Taiwan directly related to table KNA1_TW_EXT. In it, the conversion steps are explained and - guess what? - they involve manually downloading the data from table KNA1_TW_EXT while still on ECC and then - again manually - running SAP-provided program EDOC_TW_CUST_MIGRATE to add the fields' content to their "new" location which is funnily enough table KNA1! Unfortunately, we didn't have the upload program in our system and the OSS-Note wasn't applicable to our version of the S/4HANA-system anyway. 

So, the next step was to create an SAP incident to ask about the note's applicability in our system and to get some confirmation that these manual steps are actually necessary. We got both quickly and could then run through these motions in the sandbox system. And these steps will need to be added to the big check list for needed manual activities when the actual productive system gets converted sometime next year. 

The need for and fun with Retrofit

Given the long-running nature of our custom code conversion and process testing in sandbox systems, we obviously couldn't impose a freeze on the productive landscape still on Netweaver 750 EHP8 (ECC). We therefore needed a means to keep our new S/4HANA landscape up to date with new developments and applied changes in the corresponding ECC-system. With help from SAP, a Retrofit system based on Solution Manager was established and can now be used to "merge" changes applied in the ECC-system with the code in S/4HANA.

Simplified system landscape

Once transports hit our ECC productive systems, they become relevant for Retrofit in S/4HANA. The transports are automatically checked and the ones without conflicts - new objects, changed objects for which no S/4HANA code conversion has happened and which don't have S/4HANA Readiness findings - are directly imported into the S/4HANA development system. Other transports are held back for manual inspections.

While the Retrofit framework handles report programs and includes just fine by displaying differences in the two code versions side by side, it has its limitations when it comes to Adobe forms and enhancements. For these objects the side by side comparison doesn't work and it would need to be done manually via version compare which can not just be tedious but also rather error prone. Because of that, we are now asking our colleagues who applied changes in these objects in ECC to re-apply the same changes - adapted to the S/4HANA needs - in the S/4HANA development system. 

Generally and speaking from a Retrofit perspective, any change not applied in the ECC system is a good change. Even with the tools available in Retrofit, the effort increases with frequent changes in ECC to objects already converted to S/4. And with each new change, the complexity and chances for errors increases.

This concludes part 4 of our journey from SAP Netweaver to S/4HANA - I'm sure that 2026 will throw some more curve balls our way!

entry.title: Deep Dive: Multi-Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
entry.content:
This blog post was co-authored with @Cielo_SanabriaRuiz & @Sebastian1611 

Sustainability is no longer just about carbon emissions - it‚Äôs about understanding the full environmental impact of business operations along the value chain. With the next phase of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, the solution expands from a pure carbon tool to a broader environmental footprint platform: In addition to detailed analysis of greenhouse gas emissions ‚Äì including fossil, biogenic, and removed emissions ‚Äì you can now calculate and analyze your organization‚Äôs impact across a wider range of areas, such as land use , energy, waste, and resource depletion. This allows you to meet diverse reporting standards and drive operational decisions beyond decarbonization alone.

In this blog post, we‚Äôll provide you an introduction into the topic and a guided walk-through of the implementation process for multi-impact categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. You‚Äôll see how to configure your system, manage the relevant data, and run calculations so you can unlock richer, decision-ready sustainability insights.

  • Introduction
  • Configure and Calculate Footprints for Multi-Impact Categories
  • Manage Source Data
  • Manage Footprint Settings
  • Manage Emission Factors
  • Model Footprint Parameters
  • Manage Periodic Data
  • Manage Footprint Calculations
  • Analyze Footprints
  • Communicate Footprints
  • Enhancements to APIs in Business Accelerator Hub
  • Map Calculation Results to Reporting Standards

Introduction

What has changed

Since its initial release, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management has focused on calculating accurate product and corporate carbon footprints based on actual business data from SAP ERP and other sources. With the latest updates, this calculation engine now covers additional environmental impact categories so that you can monitor a wider range of environmental pressures using the same data foundation, governance model, and auditability:

Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

What multi-impact categories mean

Multi-impact categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management represent separate ‚Äúlenses‚Äù on how business activities put pressure on different parts of the Earth system, all calculated on the same data foundation. This aligns well with the planetary boundaries concept, where climate change is only one boundary among several others such as biosphere integrity, land-system change, and biogeochemical flows that together define a safe operating space for humanity.

Instead of focusing on a single metric like carbon, multi‚Äëimpact categories let you translate your operational data into a set of environmental pressure indicators that mirror those planetary boundaries dimensions. In practice, this means that for every relevant activity or product, you can see not only its contribution to climate change but also how it stresses other Earth-system limits, helping you understand whether improvements in one area inadvertently push another boundary closer to its threshold.‚Äã By structuring these indicators as configurable categories in the footprint model, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management becomes a bridge between planetary science and enterprise data, turning abstract boundary concepts into concrete KPIs based on your ERP data.

Why this matters for reporting

By going beyond carbon, you can align one consistent footprint dataset with multiple regulatory and voluntary frameworks, including emerging requirements from the EU Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) or Science-Based Targets Initiative‚Äôs Forests, Land and Agriculture (SBTi FLAG) guidance, that increasingly demand broader environmental indicators. This reduces the need for parallel tools and spreadsheet workarounds, and helps sustainability, finance, and controlling teams work from synchronized, audit-ready numbers when preparing disclosures and customer requests.‚Äã

A structured multi-impact model also strengthens the credibility of reported data, because the same calculation logic and master data serve both internal and external views. That consistency is crucial when environmental performance becomes a criterion in financing, procurement, and customer negotiations.

Why this matters for decisions

When multi-impact indicators sit next to financial and operational KPIs, sustainability data moves from a separate reporting stream into the core of how you evaluate trade-offs and investment cases. This richer impact picture helps identify where reducing environmental pressure also boosts efficiency, resilience, and brand value, and where hidden risks accumulate if planetary boundaries are ignored.‚Äã

In this way, multi-impact categories support a shift from compliance-driven reporting to performance-driven steering, where sustainability becomes a dimension of competitiveness and innovation. These updates are a concrete step in SAP‚Äôs broader vision to transform sustainability data into a catalyst for long-term business value rather than a pure cost of doing business.

How one calculation serves many requirements

In SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, the integration and calculation setup stays exactly the same as before: You still reuse your ERP data, automate activity data collection, map to imported or pre-delivered emission factors, and run one centralized footprint calculation. The difference is that this familiar approach now delivers additional impact categories and result views, so the same activity data and methods can serve a growing list of corporate and product-level requirements without extra integration projects or parallel calculation logic.

Footprint Calculation Concept in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

Configure and Calculate Footprints for Multi-Impact Categories

The overall workflow remains similar to a standard carbon footprint calculation, but with crucial distinctions in steps where you specify and assign your desired impact categories and their corresponding factors:

  • Manage Source Data: Prepare foundational data.
  • Manage Footprint Settings: Configure how footprints are calculated, including impact categories.
  • Manage Emission Factors: Define impact factors for all chosen categories and link them to purchased products.
  • Model Footprint Parameters: Refine specific calculation models (e.g., energy flow, allocations).
  • Manage Periodic Data: Input business transactional data for the calculation period.
  • Manage Footprint Calculations: Execute the footprint calculation across all selected impact categories.
  • Analyze Footprints: Review and analyze on the multi-category results on different aggregation levels.
  • Communicate Footprints: Send your calculated environmental footprints to other applications.

 

Manage Source Data

The foundational master data required for environmental impact calculations is uploaded using the Import Master Data application. There are no changes to this app, for details see: Import Master Data.

 

Manage Footprint Settings

To tailor the calculation process, select your desired configuration variant using the Manage Calculation Variants app. You can either opt for the DEFAULT variant or configure a new one. Calculation variants define various parameters, such as allocation rules and Scope 2 calculation methods, which are fundamental to the overall footprint calculation. It is important to understand how these settings influence the results across all selected impact categories to ensure consistency and accuracy. See Manage Calculation Variants for more information.

Next, go to the Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes app to define the boundaries and specific impact categories to be assessed in your environmental footprint calculation. This is a critical step when expanding beyond pure product carbon footprints (PCFs) and corporate carbon footprints (CCFs). When creating a footprint inventory scope, you can select up to ten impact categories for a single scope, including Climate Change which is always mandatory. If you enable the Accept Missing Emission Factors attribute for an impact category, any entities lacking an emission factor for that category will be excluded from its specific calculation. This attribute can be enabled for each impact category individually. For details, see Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes.

Manage Inventory Scope

 

Manage Emission Factors

To calculate footprints for your desired Impact Categories, you must provide corresponding emission and/or impact factors. SAP Sustainability Footprint Management allows you to utilize pre-delivered emission factor data packages, or you can import your own data via the Manage Emission Factors app. This is a key area where the process expands significantly when moving beyond a single CO2e factor. The key considerations for managing emission factors for multiple impact categories are the following:

  • For each impact category you wish to assess, a specific impact factor is required. Therefore, when populating either the LCA or Simple Template, you must input a separate entry for each impact category. Although these factors might relate to the same product, energy source, or business activity, they are differentiated by their distinct Impact Category ID.
  • Impact factors other than Climate Change (CLCH) must be added via Data Packages and cannot be manually inserted into the Emission Factor Periods in consuming apps such as Model Energy Flows, Manage Waste Footprints, or Manage Business Activities.
  • For importing emission factors, both the simple template (version 3) and the LCA template (version 5) in the Manage Emission Factors app have been enhanced to support multiple impact categories.

For details on maintaining emission factors data in the templates, see Emission Factors Data. Under Impact Categories, you find a table with all impact categories, including their IDs, dimensions, and indicators.

Manage Emission Factors

After importing the relevant emission factors, you can move to the Manage Purchased Product Footprints app to map your imported products from your ERP system to the previously maintained emission factor datasets. Those must include data for the Climate Change impact category and can optionally include emission data for additional ones. The mapping can be done manually or AI-assisted ‚Äì with just one mapping, all available data for the impact categories is linked automatically. Clicking on a mapped dataset, provides you with an overview of all mapped content. See Manage Purchased Product Footprints for more information.

Manage Purchased Product Footprints

Similar to purchased products, the Manage Waste Footprints app enables you to manage the values used to calculate Climate Change and other environmental impacts resulting from the treatment of a specific type of waste within a defined period. Those can also be entered manually or mapped to maintained emission factor datasets. For more details, see Manage Waste Footprints.

Finally, Business Activities allow you to calculate environmental impacts based on form-based data collection. In the Manage Business Activities app, you can create those business activities and map the corresponding emission factor. For each business activity, you can determine which GHG scope the activity relates to. Find all details under Manage Business Activities.

 

Model Footprint Parameters

When calculating impacts for energy-related and transport activities, the Manage Locations app allows you to manage relevant locations. Ensure all locations pertinent to your chosen impact categories are added. See Manage Locations for more information.

The Model Energy Flows application is crucial for managing energy consumption and its associated impacts. When creating Energy Sources and their corresponding emission factor periods, you can now connect to emission factor datasets that include impact categories beyond just Climate Change. This means that the environmental impact of energy consumption, whether from electricity, fuel, or other sources, can now be assessed not only for its carbon footprint but also for its contribution to abiotic resource depletion or other selected impact categories, provided the relevant emission factors are assigned. While you can create a full energy flow model, including meter readings to allocate energy and emissions to locations, resources and manufactured products, you may also opt to create only the relevant Energy Sources required for your Corporate Carbon Footprint calculations. In both cases, the periodic consumption values, and if enabled the corresponding meter readings, are entered later in a GHG Data Form via the Record GHG Data app. For more information, see Model Energy Flows.

Manage Energy Source

For distributing environmental impacts from senders (e.g., Business Activities, Facilities, or Waste Types) to receivers (e.g., Facilities, Process Infrastructures, or Products), you can define Allocation Schemes and Allocation Rules in the Manage Allocations app. A sender is selected and linked to one or multiple receivers. The allocation ratio determines which portion of the sender‚Äôs total impact (across all calculated impact categories) is allocated to each receiver. This ensures that the environmental impacts associated with, for example, a shared energy source are correctly attributed to the products or processes consuming that energy. Check Manage Allocations for all details.

 

Manage Periodic Data

To calculate environmental impacts related to purchased goods and services, business transactions need to be imported from your ERP system via the Import Business Transactions app. This includes data related to the movement of physical goods that are relevant for calculating product and corporate environmental impacts. Typical goods movement transactions that track the flow of products are: Opening Stock, Goods Receipt from Supplier, Goods Transfer, Goods Issue and Receipt from Production, and Internal Service Confirmation. Periodic data will be imported within the periodic boundaries defined in the Footprint Inventory Scope. These transactions form the basis for actual activity data that will be multiplied by the impact factors across all selected impact categories. Find more information under Import Business Transactions.

For capturing activity data for Energy Consumption, Meter Readings, Business Activities, and Waste Generated in Operations, the Manage GHG Data Collection and Record GHG Data applications offer a form-based data collection approach. You can enter activity values for each footprint inventory scope and period within these apps. While the apps are named with GHG, they now support the collection of activity data that will be linked to emission factors for all selected impact categories, not just greenhouse gases. For all details, see Manage GHG Data Collections and Record GHG Data.

GHG Data Collection

 

Manage Footprint Calculations

Once all data is set up and provided in the preceding steps, the organizational environmental impact for the selected impact categories can be calculated. In the Calculate Footprints app, maintain the necessary data, such as the Footprint Inventory Scope, Calculation Variant, and Period. Before initiating the calculation, it‚Äôs crucial to check for data completeness to ensure accurate results across all chosen impact categories. The calculation engine will then process all assigned impact factors against the activity data. For more information, see Calculate Footprints.

To view the detailed results per impact category, navigate to the Manage Footprint Results app or click Show Results directly within the Calculate Footprints app. You can then click on each calculated Footprint Item within the inventory to drill down into details. While the Sankey chart currently remains focused on Climate Change, the Footprint Information section now clearly displays the calculated impact categories per GHG scope (where applicable), along with the corresponding total footprint and footprint per unit for each impact category you selected. See Manage Footprint Results for details.

Manage Footprint Results

 

Analyze Footprints

For analyzing the calculated footprints, the Footprint Overview app provides a high-level summary of your impact calculation results. While the initial general overview and dashboards emphasize the Climate Change impact category, clicking on the respective dashboards allows you to navigate to more detailed analyses. See Using the Footprint Overview Application for more information.

The Corporate Balance app provides a consolidated view of your organization‚Äôs environmental performance. While it may not yet offer specific multi-impact-category features distinct from the Climate Change balance, it serves as an overarching summary. For learning more about viewing organizational upstream and downstream emissions, see Using the Corporate Balance Application.

The Purchased Products analytics app now allows you to display calculated footprints by impact category via a filter option. This enables a detailed understanding of the environmental burden associated with specific procured products across all selected impact categories, providing a richer perspective than just CO2e. For more information, see Using the Purchased Products Application.

Purchased Product Footprints Analytics

Similarly, the Sold Products analytics app offers a filter option to display the calculated footprints by impact category. This is crucial for understanding the cradle-to-gate (or other defined boundary) impacts of products your organization sells, reported across various environmental indicators. Find more details under Using the Sold Products Application.

The Energy Consumers analytics app has been enhanced to allow you to choose and display the calculated footprints by impact category through a filter option. This provides granular insights into the environmental impacts (e.g., Climate Change, Resource Depletion) associated with energy consumption for specific entities within your organization. See Using the Energy Consumers Application to learn more.

Finally, also the Waste Generated in Operations analytics app now includes a filter option, enabling you to display the calculated footprints by impact category. This allows for a comprehensive assessment of the environmental burden from internal waste management across different environmental dimensions. Find more information here: Using the Waste Generated in Operations Application.

 

Communicate Footprints

For Communicating Footprints you can use different apps to perform the configurations required to make calculated footprints available to be consumed by other systems, for example, SAP Sustainability Control Tower and SAP Cloud ERP:

The Manage Footprint Communication app allows you to configure which footprint data be shared with other systems like SAP Sustainability Control Tower. Currently, it focuses on climate change results.

With the Publish Product Footprints (internal) app, you can publish calculated Product Carbon Footprints (PCFs) to connected SAP Cloud ERP systems for business process integration.

For supply chain collaboration, you can use the Publish Product Footprints (Carbon Data Exchange) app to publish PCFs externally to customers and partners leveraging the standardized PACT format.

 

Enhancements to APIs in Business Accelerator Hub

Updates have also been made to existing APIs on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub to support the expanded impact category capabilities, now also supporting all categories in addition to Climate Change:

  • Item Footprints
  • Emission Factors

 

Map Calculation Results to Reporting Standards

To facilitate external reporting, especially for frameworks that require specific categorization of impacts, you can map your calculated impact category results to relevant reporting categories. The following figure illustrates how certain Climate Change sub-impact categories serve as building blocks to support different key reporting standards:

Impact Categories as Building Blocks for Key Reporting Standards

We plan to publish additional blog posts in the future to explain in detail how the mapping of calculated impact categories to the listed standard‚Äôs reporting categories works ‚Äì stay tuned!

For general news on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I‚Äôll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product‚Äôs new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I‚Äôm also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

entry.title: SAP Fiori tools 2601 update ‚Äì Mobile Device Preview, Building Blocks, and AI-Driven Productivity
entry.content:
With the latest SAP Fiori tools update 2601, we continue our focus on improving developer productivity, openness, and real-world usability. This release brings meaningful enhancements across previewing applications, managing system connections, building SAP Fiori elements‚Äìbased UIs, and accelerating development with AI-powered tooling. At the same time, we‚Äôve continued to refine the fundamentals in security, modelling, and extensibility.

Preview SAP Fiori Apps on Real Mobile Devices

When developing SAP Fiori applications, simulating a mobile experience in a desktop browser often isn‚Äôt enough to fully validate real-world behavior. Touch interactions, performance characteristics, and device-specific rendering can differ noticeably on physical phones and tablets.

To address this, SAP Fiori tools now supports previewing applications directly on real mobile devices when using @sap/ux-ui5-tooling version 1.19.1 or higher. By creating a new run configuration and enabling Remote Access, developers can expose the local preview. When the run configuration is started, the terminal provides connection details, including a URL and a QR code, which can be opened directly on a phone or tablet to access the running app.

This makes it significantly easier to validate layouts, navigation, and interactions exactly as end users will experience them without leaving the development environment.

Showcase for previewing a SAP Fiori elements app on iPhone

A New Connection Manager for SAP Systems in VS Code

Managing connections to remote SAP systems is a foundational task when working with SAP Fiori tools. With this release, we introduce the Connection Manager for SAP Systems as a dedicated Visual Studio Code extension. This new extension succeeds the previously integrated saved systems panel from the Application Modeler and provides a focused, extensible solution for handling system connections in Visual Studio Code.

The Connection Manager allows developers to create, store, test, and edit connection information that can be reused by the SAP Fiori generator as well as by preview features in SAP Fiori tools. Storing passwords is optional, and if stored, they are protected by the security policies of your operating system's credential manager.

By making this capability standalone and open source, it is now accessible to other extensions such as the Service Catalog extension, and open for community contributions.

Connection Manager

Expanded Support for SAP Fiori Elements Building Blocks

SAP Fiori tools continues to enhance the support for the building blocks which shape the framework of SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 and its flexibility you can use. It makes it easier to create and adapt applications using a structured, metadata-driven approach while keeping flexibility in design. In this update, the Page Editor gains additional capabilities that improve developer convenience when working with custom pages and sections.

Developers can now add more building block types to their apps with the Page Editor, including rich text editors within custom sections, custom columns for table building blocks, and the page building block itself. Managing custom pages is also more intuitive, as building blocks can now be deleted directly from the editor. To support experimentation and iteration, undo and redo actions are now available when working on custom pages.

Together, these enhancements reduce friction when adapting applications and allow developers to work more confidently and efficiently with SAP Fiori elements‚Äìbased UIs.

Rich Text Editor building block support in Page Editor

Enhancements Across the AI-Toolchain

AI capabilities continue to evolve across SAP Fiori tools, with a strong focus on usability and enabling deeper end-to-end changes from within the tooling.

The Project Accelerator can now be launched directly from the SAP Fiori generator, streamlining the initial project creation flow. The previously required staging step has been removed, allowing new projects to be created directly in the selected workspace folder. For projects created using the Project Accelerator, the Application Modeler now offers advanced editing capabilities, such as creating new fields and properties end-to-end, updating the data model, exposing the service, and consuming the changes in the UI in one coherent flow.

AI support has also been extended to mock data generation. Developers can generate realistic mock data using AI directly in the Application Modeler, and this capability is available for all applications whenever the Project Accelerator is enabled.

In parallel, the MCP server for SAP Fiori continues to expand. The server now exposes @sap-ux/create commands as CLI functionality, enabling reliable execution in MCP-supported workflows. App generation has been extended to support CAP Java projects, and a new ‚Äúsearch_docs‚Äù tool allows the LLM (Large Language Model) to query SAP Fiori elements documentation, annotations, SAP Fiori tools documentation, and SAP Fiori Development Portal resources to quickly find relevant guidance and code snippets.

Continuous Improvements and Refinements

Beyond the headline features, this release includes a range of continuous improvements that strengthen the overall development experience. Newly created CAP applications now use NPM workspaces by default, establishing best practices out of the box and enabling the use of @sap/ux-ui5-tooling middlewares when previewing CAP-based applications.

The Application Modeler has been enhanced with additional SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 features, including support for hidden draft mode, improved configuration options for table create dialogs, and create support for custom fields in form sections. These additions give developers more control over application behavior without leaving the modeling environment.

Security and user management have also been strengthened. The ABAP Cloud connection type in the Connection Manager has been consolidated around re-entrance ticket authentication, moving away from service key‚Äìbased authentication. This eliminates long-lived shared credentials and ties system access directly to the signed-in user, improving both security and maintainability.

Looking Ahead

We are already working on the next set of enhancements for SAP Fiori tools. Planned improvements include a rework and enhancement of OPA5 test generation, with added support for value help services and mock data generation. Project validation will be extended with new domain-specific ESLint rule sets, visualized directly in the Application Modeler, alongside support for ESLint 9.

Support for additional SAP Fiori elements building blocks, such as form and field, is also on the roadmap. On the AI side, we continue to improve the robustness and usefulness of responses from the MCP server, while the Project Accelerator will be extended to support RAP service creation.

As always, we look forward to your feedback and contributions as we continue to evolve SAP Fiori tools together with the community.

entry.title: Future-ready SAP systems: The role of Clean Core, BTP, and automated change management
entry.content:
As organizations shift to S/4HANA or embrace the Cloud, many are discovering that success is more than just a technology upgrade. It's rethinking how your SAP systems are architected, customized (or extended), and managed. Underlying this is the challenge of innovating quickly while ensuring compliance and system stability.

In this scenario, Clean Core is becoming a foundation for optimizing your SAP environment and future-proofing your SAP systems. Adopting a Clean Core strategy doesn't mean sacrificing business-critical customization or overhauling your ERP systems. You don't have to choose between control and innovation. 

In combination with the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and automated SAP change management, you can modernize your SAP landscape, easily manage change across on-premises and the Cloud, and prepare for the future. 

What is Clean Core, and why does it matter?

Historically, organizations have relied heavily on customizing their SAP system to meet their specific requirements. While this was effective in the short term, these modifications have unintentionally led, over time, to what is commonly known as a dirty core.

 And the cost of a dirty core can be high:

  • Complex and costly upgrades that take longer and are riskier
  • Increased technical debt that slows down innovation
  • Higher total cost of ownership (TCO) due to inefficiencies and ongoing maintenance challenges

Embracing a Clean Core approach addresses these issues. A clean core means keeping your core ERP system as close to standard as possible. It doesn‚Äôt mean no more customizations. Custom applications and extensions are built using released APIs and extensibility options ‚Äì on-stack and side-by-side ‚Äì which in most cases are external to your core ERP.

Yet, achieving the objectives of Clean Core isn‚Äôt just about moving custom code to the appropriate development layer. It‚Äôs about following long-established development best practices and using a disciplined approach to design and build a solution.

Without this discipline, adopting a Clean Core methodology doesn‚Äôt guarantee a low total cost of ownership or a problem-free future. You can still create brittle and expensive code ‚Äúoutside the core ERP‚Äù that can cause performance issues, break during upgrades, or introduce unnecessary complexity.

Other practical challenges to be aware of include:

  • The API you need to support your business may not yet be available to support the business requirement in a Clean Core-compliant way. You can request a new API from SAP, but waiting can delay your Clean Core journey
  • Upskilling teams and partners to work in the new ways needed, and finding the information to navigate the journey needs planning and preparation

These hurdles don‚Äôt undermine the value of adopting a Clean Core methodology. A Clean Core and well-implemented code establish a foundation for faster and more predictable SAP upgrades, aligning your business objectives with your ERP investments.

SAP BTP: Innovation without cluttering the core

Organizations still need to innovate, differentiate and extend SAP systems to meet business requirements (without adding technical debt). That‚Äôs where SAP BTP comes in.

SAP BTP is a Cloud-based platform that enables you to develop applications, integrate systems, and extend functionality without directly altering your core ERP. This separation is key to maintaining a Clean Core while customizing SAP to your needs. Custom development becomes more loosely coupled with the Core and this reduces interference with SAP upgrades or performance.

How SAP BTP can help achieve and maintain a Clean Core:

  1. Side-by-side extensibility: Build and run custom applications on BTP, keeping your core ERP clean and stable
  2. Integrations: Use SAP Integration Suite to connect SAP and non-SAP systems without modifying the core
  3. Advanced capabilities: Access solutions and services like SAP analytics, AI, and machine learning to enhance decision-making without risking unscheduled downtime of your core SAP system

With SAP BTP you can innovate faster and build scalable applications and extensions that evolve independently of SAP‚Äôs upgrade cycle.

However, BTP is not the only way to achieve a Clean Core. SAP provides a multi-tier extensibility model for creating and maintaining customizations independently from the core. For example, you can make minor, non-disruptive extensions directly within your S/4HANA core system without directly modifying SAP standard code.

Why automated change management still matters

Adopting a Clean Core strategy and using SAP BTP to drive your business transformation and future-proof your SAP systems doesn‚Äôt eliminate the need to manage change.

It‚Äôs not enough to follow best practices when developing SAP changes. You must also apply the same level of discipline to managing, governing, and delivering those changes safely through your SAP landscape.

Whether you are making configuration changes in your core ERP (ECC or S/4HANA) or building applications on the BTP, changes must be managed effectively without interrupting daily business operation. This is where automating change management plays a crucial role. Change must be controlled, traceable, and compliant with regulatory requirements and internal governance.

Automating and enforcing change management ensures:

  • Consistency ‚Äì every change whether on premises or in the Cloud (BTP) follows a standard, pre-defined process
  • Compliance ‚Äì internal policies and external regulations are met through configurable automated workflows
  • Visibility ‚Äì full transparency into every change including what was changed and who approved, ensuring accountability and integrity of the change delivery process

A future-ready SAP system isn‚Äôt just about where changes happen (core ERP or Cloud) but also how they‚Äôre managed across a hybrid landscape.

The big picture: Digital Transformation and future-ready SAP systems

Clean Core, SAP BTP, and automated change management are not separate strategies, they‚Äôre interdependent.

  • Clean Core is the foundation: a simplified, upgrade-ready ERP environment
  • SAP BTP gives you the tools and services to build customizations and extensions without compromising that foundation
  • Automated change management ensures that every change is delivered safely, consistently, and with minimal disruption

Together, a Clean Core strategy, SAP BTP, and automated change management can help you to speed up your digital transformation, move to the Cloud more easily, and future-proof your SAP systems.

entry.title: Invoice Submission to the Singapore Tax Authority: How to Automate Invoice Note Filling in XML Files
entry.content:
Are you a GST-registered business in Singapore subject to the GST InvoiceNow Requirement? If so, you need to submit invoice data electronically to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS). This may include providing invoice notes in XML files submitted to IRAS. This blog provides guidance on how you can automate this step.

A few quick notes:

  • SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition is the solution to support GST InvoiceNow requirements. For an overview, check out this blog: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for Singapore GST InvoiceNow.
  • This blog applies to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, SAP S/4HANA, and SAP ERP.
  • This blog quotes information from some IRAS guidelines. The quoted information is accurate as of the publication date of the blog. As these IRAS guidelines are subject to change, we recommend checking the latest versions for the most current information.

 

What Is an Invoice Note?

Here‚Äôs the definition of invoice note from TX2 - Annex - Data Specification:

A textual note that gives unstructured information that is relevant to the Invoice as a whole such as the reason for any correction or assignment note in case the invoice has been factored.

An invoice note is displayed in one of these XML elements, depending on the invoice type:

  • ubl:Invoice / cbc:Note for invoices
  • ubl:CreditNote / cbc:Note for credit notes

IRAS specifies the scenarios where an invoice note is mandatory, such as credit notes and self-billing invoices. For certain special scenarios, IRAS prescribes their note texts. For example, according to the e-Tax Guide ‚ÄúAdopting GST InvoiceNow Requirement for GST-registered Businesses (First Edition)‚Äù, you must include this exact note text in self-billing invoices:

The invoice is a Buyer Created Tax Invoice. The tax shown is your output tax due to the Comptroller of GST.

 

The Challenge: Automating Beyond the Standard

To include an invoice note in a submitted XML file, you need to enter the note text in a specific source document field. For those scenarios that require specific note texts, it would be a great time-saver if the system can fill in them automatically. The standard solution already does this for these scenarios:

  • Self-billing invoices
  • Customer invoices with the GST category code SRCA-S (Customer accounting supply made by supplier)
  • Supplier invoices with the GST category code TXCA (Standard-rated purchases of prescribed goods subject to customer accounting)

What about other scenarios? Manually entering invoice notes is really time-consuming and prone to error.

 

The Solution: BAdI to the Rescue

You can define your own logic for populating invoice notes using the following Business Add-Ins (BAdIs):

ProductBAdI
  • SAP S/4HANA
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  • SAP ERP
EDOC_ADAPTOR: SET_OUTPUT_DATA method
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public EditionEDOC_ADAPTOR_Cloud: SET_OUTPUT_DATA method

In this blog, we'll show you how to create a BAdI implementation that populates invoice notes for customer invoices (eDocument type: SGC5C_INV) in these scenarios based on the tax code:

ScenarioInvoice Note Text Prescribed by IRASTax Code You Use
Gross Margin SchemeThe transaction is under the Gross Margin Scheme.S1
Approved Marine Fuel Trader SchemeThe Payment of GST is not required under the AMFT Scheme.Z1
Discounted Sale Price SchemeThe transaction is under the Discounted Sale Price Scheme.Z2

 

Step-by-Step Guide: Sample BAdI Implementation in SAP S/4HANA, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, and SAP ERP

Step 1: Create a customer package.

Some objects are created when you create a BAdI implementation. To transport these objects across a customer landscape, create a customer package or choose an existing customer package.

Step 2: Create an enhancement implementation.

In this example, we create an implementation named ZEI_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 by doing the following:

  1. Call up the SE19 transaction.
  2. Select the New BAdI radio button in the Create Implementation section and enter ES_EDOCUMENT in the Enhancement Spot field. Choose Create.



  3. Enter ZEI_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 as the enhancement implementation name and Implementation: eDocument Adaptor Singapore as the short text. Choose Continue.



    When prompted for a package, enter the package created or chosen in step 1.

  4. In the window that appears next, do the following:
    • Enter ZEI_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 as the BAdI implementation name.
    • Enter ZCL_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 as the implementation class.
    • Select the BAdI definition EDOC_ADAPTOR.

  5. Choose Continue. When prompted for a package, enter the package created or chosen in step 1.
  6. Activate your changes.
  7. Expand the tree for the BAdI implementation you just created. Double-click Filter Values.



  8. In the filter values details on the right, choose Create Filter Combination. 



  9. In the Choose Filter dialog, select COUNTRY. Choose Continue.
  10. Double-click the COUNTRY filter.
  11. In the Display Filter Value dialog, enter SG as Value 1 and select = as Comparator 1. Choose Continue.



    The filter combination you just created looks like this: 



Step 3: Update the ZCL_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 class.

  1. Call up the SE24 transaction.
  2. Enter the object type ZCL_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5. Choose Change.



  3. Double-click the method IF_EDOC_ADAPTOR~SET_OUTPUT_DATA.



  4. Add the sample code below into this method:
        FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_mwskz> TYPE mwskz,
                       <fs_tax_data_tab> TYPE any,
                       <fs_tax_data> TYPE any.

        io_source->get_data_reference(
          RECEIVING
            rd_data = DATA(lv_data)
        ).

        IF lv_data IS NOT INITIAL.
          ASSIGN COMPONENT 'TAX_DATA' OF STRUCTURE lv_data->* to <fs_tax_data_tab>.
          IF <fs_tax_data_tab> IS ASSIGNED.
            LOOP AT <fs_tax_data_tab> ASSIGNING <fs_tax_data>.
              ASSIGN COMPONENT 'MWSKZ' OF STRUCTURE <fs_tax_data> TO <fs_mwskz>.
              IF sy-subrc = 0.
                CASE <fs_mwskz>.
                  WHEN 'S1'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The transaction is under the Gross Margin Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN 'Z1'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The Payment of GST is not required under the AMFT Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN 'Z2'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The transaction is under the Discounted Sale Price Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN OTHERS.
                ENDCASE.
              ENDIF.
            ENDLOOP.
          ENDIF.
        ENDIF.‚Äã


5. Save and activate your changes.

 

Guidance for Customers Using SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

You need to add the sample code below into the SET_OUTPUT_DATA method of the EDOC_ADAPTOR_Cloud BAdI:

Tip: 
For a step-by-step guide on how to implement this BAdI, check out the following blog:
Enhancing the Standard XML File for Electronic Documents using the BAdI EDOC_ADAPTOR_CLOUD 

 

        FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_mwskz> TYPE mwskz,
                       <fs_tax_data_tab> TYPE any,
                       <fs_tax_data> TYPE any.

        io_source->get_data_reference(
          RECEIVING
            rd_data = DATA(lv_data)
        ).

        IF lv_data IS NOT INITIAL.
          ASSIGN COMPONENT 'TAX_DATA' OF STRUCTURE lv_data->* to <fs_tax_data_tab>.
          IF <fs_tax_data_tab> IS ASSIGNED.
            LOOP AT <fs_tax_data_tab> ASSIGNING <fs_tax_data>.
              ASSIGN COMPONENT 'MWSKZ' OF STRUCTURE <fs_tax_data> TO <fs_mwskz>.
              IF sy-subrc = 0.
                CASE <fs_mwskz>.
                  WHEN 'S1'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The transaction is under the Gross Margin Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN 'Z1'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The Payment of GST is not required under the AMFT Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN 'Z2'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The transaction is under the Discounted Sale Price Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN OTHERS.
                ENDCASE.
              ENDIF.
            ENDLOOP.
          ENDIF.
        ENDIF.

 

Wrapping Up

Hope this blog is helpful for you. We'd love to hear feedback from you. Feel free to share comments below. Let's learn from each other!

To learn more about the solution, refer to the following documentation on SAP Help Portal, which covers business task procedures, configuration, and more:

ProductDocumentation Links

  • Electronic Supplier Invoices: Submission to the Tax Authority

entry.title: Resolve Overprotection
entry.content:
Resolve Overprotection

Customers easily understand the benefits of supply protection. Protecting quantities for specific customers, regions, or any defined group is a common use case in shortage situations (to learn more about supply protection check the blog titled Supply Protection in a Nutshell). 

However, protecting too much can run into the issue known as overprotection. 

S/4HANA 2025 offers a solution to identify and mitigate overprotection. 

What is Overprotection?

Every requirement, such as a sales order, must adhere to the restrictions defined by supply protection. If there is stock available but not every request receive confirmation due to supply protection, this situation is referred to as overprotection. 

The following illustration helps to understand the definition of overprotection. 


Illustration 1: Overprotection

On the left side of the illustration, a blue bar shows the available stock or supply. Colored boxes indicate the defined remaining protection for France (purple), Italy (green) and Germany (orange). Grey boxes represent the restrictions from the perspective of the related supply protection objects. In this example, the horizontal red line represents the available stock. For a demand matching the supply protection object for Germany, the grey boxes for Italy (3000) and France (4500) are to be considered as restrictions. Therefore, even a demand matching the priority 1 protection group for Germany doesn‚Äôt receive confirmation. All other potential demands also exceed the red line. This means, in all cases, the restrictions surpass availability. 

Other critical Situations


Illustration 2: Blocked SUP Objects

Assuming the stock is slightly higher, there won‚Äôt be overprotection. Demands that match the priority 1 protection for SUP Germany could receive confirmation. However, even this situation might still be considered as critical because complete markets, such as France and Italy, are blocked. In some cases, it might be acceptable that complete supply protection objects are blocked, but, in other situations, this is likely unintended and treated as a critical problem. 

If there is more supply (illustration 3), supply protection works as intended ‚Äì some demands are blocked, and only high-prioritized demands receive confirmation. Depending on the situation, this can also be seen as critical, especially if the planned protection is defined with the setting Restriction outside planned Protection. It‚Äôs obvious that other demands (not matching a protection) won‚Äôt receive confirmation. 


Illustration 3: Blocked SUP Groups

Identify Overprotection and other critical Situations

Overprotection was considered as issue because it was difficult to identify. It doesn‚Äôt appear in any app that shows availability. Within a sales order, users can see that supply protection prevents order confirmation. However, they can‚Äôt see that all other orders for the same material-plant-combination are also blocked. 

Overprotection can occur at the Restricted Product level. A restricted product is the combination of a plant-material and the defined planning level, such as plant/storage location, plant/segment, or plant/batch, for which supply protection is defined and active. 

Since supply protection is only a virtual restriction, depending on the context, the system didn‚Äôt indicate critical situations involving blocked supply protection objects.  

This has changed with the new Resolve Overprotection app which displays overprotection and other critical situations. Additionally, users can use Situation Management to receive alerts.  

Alerting for Overprotection

Customers can use the situation template CA_ATP_SUP_OVERPROTECTION to customize alerts based on their needs. Users can choose whether to receive alerts for overprotection situations or for other critical situations. Situation Management offers various settings for alert recipients, technology, and relevant criteria. 

App Resolve Overprotection

The Resolve Overprotection app provides users with a quick overview of the restricted products. By default, it sorts these restricted products on the criticality of the check result status. 


Illustration 4: The "Resolve Overprotection" App


Illustration 5: ‚ÄúResolve Overprotection‚Äù Result List

Users can view the planning level of the restricted product, the check result status, and the number of blocked supply protection objects and blocked supply protection groups.  

They can also navigate to the details of a restricted product. Here, users can see if and how much available quantity is accessible for each related protection group.


Illustration 6: Restricted Product Details View

Mitigate Overprotection

Starting from the overprotection details, users can navigate to the individual supply protection objects. They can adjust the protected quantities to improve the situation. Returning to the details page of the restricted product displays the updated check result status after retrieving the updated data using the Refresh button. 

As an alternative, you can also switch to edit mode by clicking the Edit button to simulate different mitigation options. Three different options are displayed: 

  • Prioritized reduction 
    The planned protection of all time buckets is reduced by a certain percentage. Protection groups with high priority get a low percentage reduction, while protection groups with low priority will get a high percentage reduction. 
  • Zero protection for the lowest priority 
    Only the protected quantities of the protection group with the lowest priority for each supply protection object are reduced. The reduction is 100%, completely removing the restriction by this group. 
  • Reduced Restriction Quantity by Percentage 
    The protected quantity of all related time buckets is reduced by the same percentage. 

Users can simulate the different options and decide whether to save the changes or choose another mitigation strategy. The app provides information if there is a positive available quantity accessible for the individual protection groups. There isn‚Äôt a clear recommendation for the best mitigation strategy. Users can apply the same or a different mitigation strategy after the initial one. 


Illustration 7: Mitigate Overprotection

‚ÄúOverprotection‚Äù not Addressed by the App

The Resolve Overprotection app identifies situations where supply protection restrictions exceed the available stock or supply. However, some lock issues won‚Äôt be identified as overprotection. 

For example: Suppose there is protection for one or more groups that could use the protection because there is unrestricted stock. However, matching demands are blocked by other restrictions, such as a credit block or a fully consumed product allocation (PAL) bucket. In this case, these blocked groups can‚Äôt use the defined protection, and other demands from other groups are also blocked by this non-consumable restriction. This issue arises from the setup of protection combined with the setup of product allocation.   

Summary

With the Resolve Overprotection app, along with its alerting feature, makes it easy to identify issues like overprotection and other critical situations. You can also easily mitigate the issues and overcome mutual blocking caused by supply protection. 

Nevertheless, it is crucial to set up supply protection correctly and protect only minimum quantities. There are best practices available to avoid overprotection already at an early stage. 

The setup of Supply Protection (SUP) together with Product Allocation (PAL) should be done with care. It‚Äôs recommended to use similar characteristics when defining groups in SUP and PAL. In PAL, you typically define a maximum quantity while supply protection represents minimum quantities. The interplay of both methods works best when there‚Äôs a corridor between these quantities.

entry.title: MCP Server for SAP ECC & S/4HANA: Unlimited ABAP Add-On for Display, Create and Update Tools
entry.content:
Introduction

It‚Äôs time to simplify integration processes between Agentic SDKs and SAP ECC & S/4HANA systems. We‚Äôd like to introduce an ABAP add-on that brings an MCP Server directly into your SAP ERP system and supports SAP ABAP releases down to 7.01.

Sounds attractive? Then let‚Äôs take a look at the architecture.

Architecture

The architecture is simple. We kept in mind that you may want to avoid middleware (such as SAP BTP applications or similar solutions) while retaining full control over:

  • Tool descriptions
    These are essential for AI orchestration‚Äìfriendly tool definitions. Standard SAP descriptions of services, tables, or other ABAP objects are not sufficient to build scalable Business AI solutions.

  • Data provisioning
    We provide a simple mechanism that allows you to nominate Tables, Views, and CDS Views to provision data to an Agentic SDK.

  • Create / Update / Delete tool onboarding
    We offer an easy mechanism to develop ABAP classes for create, update, and delete actions. Each tool requires only one method for the action and one method for metadata description.

This is how you can integrate it into any Agentic SDK:

Pic. 1. MCP Server at the SAP backend system level

What Does ‚ÄúUnlimited Display Tools‚Äù Mean?

There is an ABAP view where you can onboard Tables, Views, and CDS Views for data provisioning. Each object is automatically converted into a tool by the MCP Server.

 Pic. 2. Nomination of Tables, Views, and CDS Views for data provisioning via MCP Server

How Do You Develop Tools for Create / Update / Delete Actions?

We provide an ABAP interface that helps you create an ABAP class for each tool.

 Pic. 3. MCP Server tool creation for Create / Update / Delete actions

Really Any Agentic SDK?

Yes, absolutely. Here is an example of MCP Server consumption in ChatGPT.

The MCP Server can be connected either directly via an SICF node or through the SAP Cloud Connector.

 Pic. 4. MCP Server SICF node

In ChatGPT, you can connect the SAP MCP Server in developer mode:

 Pic. 5. Connecting MCP Server in ChatGPT

Once connected, you have direct access to SAP backend data from ChatGPT:

 Pic. 6. Leave request creation from ChatGPT via Skybuffer AI MCP Server

 Pic. 7. Purchase order data display from ChatGPT via Skybuffer AI MCP Server

Can Skybuffer AI MCP Server Work with SAP Joule?

Yes, absolutely. You can connect the MCP Server directly to an SAP Joule tool in SAP Joule Studio.

Conclusion

You now have a powerful, scalable MCP Server operating directly at the ABAP layer. You can provide high-quality tool descriptions, fully control display tool provisioning, and easily onboard create, update, and delete tools without the need to build OData services on top of them.

The solution works with any Agentic SDK and is ready for enterprise deployment as an ABAP add-on.
